text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in Serbian and Montenegrin press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories nor does it vouch for their accuracy.
-- S E R B I A --
POLITIKA
- Newly-elected Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic will take his presidential oath in front of both houses of the federal parliament on Wednesday.
- Serbia has entered a process of radical reforms following the adoption of the privatisation law, said Serbian Privatisation Minister Milan Beko.

- Serbian government endorses issue of long-term foreign currency bonds of Serbian Power Industry Elektroprivreda Srbije with funds to be used for rehauling of the energy system. The government also approved issue of short term bonds of the Commodity Reserve Agency to pay 1997 wheat purchase.
- Yugoslavia's Agrobanka will finance the purchase of 1997 wheat crop with 68.3 million dinars.
- Yugoslavia to resume talks with the London Club and Paris Club of creditors soon to discuss rescheduling of its debts. Talks expected to be extremely tough according to a senior banker.
- Italy interested in railway modernisation projects in Yugoslavia, particularly the Belgrade-Bar and the Valjevo- Loznica stretches, officials of Italian railway companies said.

- Largest tidal wave on the Danube has entered Yugoslavia and is expected to reach 720 cm which requires declaration of emergency measures against floods according to the Novi Sad hydrometorologic centre.
- Disbanding parliament and early elections are the only solution to the crisis in the Montenegrin leadership, said Montenegrin Deputy Parliament Speaker Zoran Zizic.
- The Socialist Party of Serbia will determine its candidate for the upcoming presidential elections by the end of the week.

- The International War Crimes Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia has forwarded sealed indictments to SFOR in Bosnia which has the mandate to arrest persons on the list if they come across them and recognise them, said SFOR spokesman Michael Wright.

- Player's of Croatian soccer team Kroacija have arrived for for the first leg match in the European Champion's Cup qualifyers with Belgrade's Partizan. This is their first match played in the teritory of the former Yugoslavia since the breakup of the federation.
NASA BORBA
- Montenegro is not in any kind of state of emergency, said Montenegrin Parliament Speaker Svetozar Marovic.
- One of the largest opposition parties, the Serbian Renewal Movement, announced the possibilty of boycotting the upcoming presidential and parliamentary elections due to unfavourable conditions.
- The elections cannot be stopped by anyone and they will be legitimate regardless of the announced opposition boycott, said the Yugoslav Left (JUL), a ruling coalition partner.
- The federal communications ministry shut down practically all private radio stations in Pozarevac, Kucevo and Veliko Gradiste over inadequate licences.
- Chemical factory Petrohemija from Pancevo is preparing for privatisation under the newly adopted law.
- Hundreds of trucks with scrap iron for the Niksic iron works are entering Montenegro from Albania daily.
VECERNJE NOVOSTI

- Zastava cars and France's Peugeot expected to sign a cooperation agreement before August 1 to produce tools and presses. Joint car production planned in a later phase. - An additional 50,000 tonnes of petrol and 20,000 tonnes of diesel need to be imported, said the Yugoslav Chamber of Commerce.
POLITIKA EKSPRES

- First half results this year are good with industrial output growth of 7.6 percent, stable exchange rate and prices, the only bad indicator is the foreign trade deficit which exceeds one billion dollars, said the Yugoslav Chamber of Commerce.
- The draft of the new federal penal code replaces the death penalty with life sentence.
GRADJANIN
- Newly-elected Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic is expected to visit Bosnian Serb President Biljana Plavsic in Banja Luka next week according to a paper source.
-- MONTENEGRO --
POBJEDA

- Montenegrin parliament opened a discussion on the initative of the Socialist Party of Serbia for constitutional changes for direct election of the Yugoslav president. The oppositon claimed the election of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic was illegal because parliamentary procedure was not observed. The session resumes on Thursday.
